A law of composition on a set $M$ is said to be associative if $(ab)c = a(bc)$ for all elements $a, b, c \in M$.
A finite group G is called a p-group if the order of G is a power of p, where p is a prime number.
Does the concept of a/an Associative Law need to be defined for a definition of a/an p-group to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a p-group involves the concept of a group, which inherently includes the associative law as part of its definition. A group, by definition, is a set equipped with a binary operation that satisfies three axioms: closure, associativity, and the existence of an identity element and inverses for each element in the set. Therefore, the associative law is a fundamental part of the definition of any group, including p-groups. Since a p-group is a type of group, the associative law must already be satisfied for the concept of a p-group to make sense. Thus, the associative law does not need to be separately defined for the definition of a p-group to be valid; it is implicitly included within the broader definition of a group.
